awd_titl_txt: The Genetics and Genomics of Local Adaptation and Acclimation in Panicum Grasses
awd_abstract_narration:
Co-PIs: Jeremy Schmutz (HudsonAlpha Institute for Biotechnology); Phil Fay (University of Texas  Environmental Science Institute)
Senior Collaborators: Tim Keitt (University of Texas at Austin); David Lowry (Michigan State University)

A major challenge facing the world is the growing demand for energy along with increasing populations and changing environments. Although predictions vary, it is likely that the future will bring alterations to current weather patterns, with impacts on temperature and precipitation in particular. Research is needed to understand how these changes will affect agricultural productivity and to investigate whether the geographical ranges of crops and native plants will shift. This project uses genetic and genomic approaches to discover how the long-lived grass switchgrass and its relatives are able to respond and adapt naturally to environmental stresses in a range of diverse habitats.  A major focus of the research is to identify genes involved in local adaptation and drought tolerance across a latitudinal gradient in the US. Ultimately, this information will provide a basis for understanding how plants adapt to varying conditions and will provide tools to engineer stress resistance crops. Undergraduate students will be engaged in the project and will gain hands-on research experiences that span disciplinary and continental boundaries.

Although there is compelling evidence for local adaptation in plants, the genetic basis underlying these adaptations is not fully understood. In particular, it is unclear how genetic trade-offs at individual loci underlie the overall pattern of adaptation or the spatial scale of those effects. Moreover, the role of epigenetic "memory" of stress in perennial plants and their long term adaptation is largely unexplored. The integrative research in this project investigates local adaptation and acclimation in Panicum grasses. The specific objectives are to (1) conduct field QTL experiments to test for divergence, local adaptation, and genotype-by-environment interaction in upland and lowland switchgrass ecotypes, (2) fine-map and clone drought tolerance QTL in diploid Panicum hallii, (3) investigate the ecological and molecular drivers of drought legacy effects, and (4) conduct genome scans of climate adaptation in Panicum hallii. Another major goal is to train the next generation of plant scientists through an REU-type program that engages Freshman undergraduate students in research at the start of their education. The findings from this project will facilitate ongoing efforts to engineer crops for higher performance under drought conditions, one of the major limitations in agricultural productivity. All sequence data will be deposited in the NCBI short read archive (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra) and at Phytozome (http://phytozome.jgi.doe.gov/pz/portal.html). Phenotypic and other data will be publicly available through journal publications and the project website (https://sites.cns.utexas.edu/juenger_lab/switchgrass).

por.por_cntn:
Although predictions vary, most climate scientists believe increase in atmospheric C02 is causing severe alterations to current weather patterns with potentially dramatic consequences for the natural world. Can natural populations adapt to these changing conditions?  If so, what limits the adaptation of plant populations to changing climates? How will future crop plants fare in the face of changing climate? Our project focused on studies of climate adaptation in C4 perennial grasses, including switchgrass (Panicum virgatum) and Hall's panic grass (Panicum hallii), using a combination of field experiments and genomic tools.  These species are common members of grassland communities in the North America that have experienced dynamic climate histories in the recent past.  Switchgrass is of special interest as a potential feedstock for biofuels.  Growing switchgrass as a feedstock may help mitigate greenhouse gas emissions by providing carbon neutral fuels in the future.

Our project helped to assemble and characterize the genomes of both Panicum virgatum and Panicum hallii.  This accomplishment provided us with critical information allowing us to use genetic mapping and a variety of genomic assays to better understand the genes involved in adaptive traits, how these genes interact with the environment, and what limits the adaptation of plants to diverse environmental conditions.  Our project utilized experimental rainout shelters in central Texas to study drought, and common garden plantings at 10 sites across North American to explore more diverse climatic variation and its impact on plant performance.  We discovered a number of important regulators of drought and habitat adaptation in both switchgrass and panicgrass.  In panicgrass, we found that regulation of gene expression was linked to drought stress responses and adaptation to inland versus coastal habitats. In switchgrass, we found that genes involved in climate adaptation were abundant, but varied considerably among deeply diverged regional ecotypes associated with the Northern Midwest, Atlantic coast, or Southern Gulf coast regions.  We found few genetic tradeoffs, suggesting that targeted breeding could potentially improve the general vigor of switchgrass as a biofuel crop. We also discovered that adaptive introgression (gene flow of adaptive alleles from one population to another) was key to northern range expansions following climate warming in the past.  Together, these studies provide new insights into how plants have coped with past climate change and current abiotic stresses.  Our findings may facilitate ongoing efforts to engineer and improve crops for higher performance under drought and winter freezing conditions, along with other environmental stresses, as well as expand our understanding of the evolution of climate adaptation.

Our project also trained scores of undergraduate researchers in Integrative Plant Biology through the Freshman Research Initiative (https://cns.utexas.edu/fri) at the University of Texas at Austin.  This program involves the development of multiple semester "research streams" for small cohorts of students with traditional lecture content, but also emphasizing hand-on training, independent research, and close interaction with faculty mentors and project scientists.  Our stream focused on the "Biology of Biofuels" and incorporated content and research projects in plant physiology, plant genetics and genomics, plant breeding, environmental biology and climate change under the umbrella of switchgrass as a model biofuel feedstock.  We also mentored summer undergraduate researchers through the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program.  Students conducted detailed studies of plant physiology, anatomy, studies of plant-natural enemy interactions, and conducted genetic mapping using C4 perennial grasses as part of a collaborative research community. These independent research experiences gave students a unique view into academic and applied research, increased STEM retention, and helped to train the next generation of integrative plant biologists.
